instruction: What kinds of spectrum were used in the related study to analyze the Italian Extra Virgin Olive Oil (EVOO) dataset?
Output: Attenuated total Reflectance-Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR) was used in the related study.

instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were employed in the related study to analyze the Italian Extra Virgin Olive Oil (EVOO) dataset?
Output: Soft Independent Modelling of Class Analogy (SIMCA), Support Vector Machine Regression (SVMR), and Principal Component Regression (PCR) were employed in the related study to analyze the Italian Extra Virgin Olive Oil (EVOO) dataset.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the results of the geographical traceability, cultivar, and repeatability analysis in the related study to analyze the Italian Extra Virgin Olive Oil (EVOO) dataset, and how far can this metric go?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the results of the geographical traceability, cultivar, and repeatability analysis in the related study on Italian EVOO dataset was the attenuated total Reflectance-Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR) coupled with Machine Learning. This metric can go as far as verifying the geographical traceability, cultivar, repeatability of agronomical practices, and detecting adulterated EVOO from soy and corn.

instruction: What machine learning models were employed in the related study to analyze the Italian Extra Virgin Olive Oil (EVOO) dataset and achieve the purpose of monitoring quality, traceability, and safety assessment?
Output: Classification and regression algorithms were employed in the related study to analyze the Italian Extra Virgin Olive Oil (EVOO) dataset and achieve the purpose of monitoring quality, traceability, and safety assessment.

instruction: Can the non-destructive analytical technique of attenuated total Reflectance-Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR) be used to achieve the purpose of monitoring quality, traceability, and safety assessment of Italian Extra Virgin Olive Oil (EVOO) and prevent food fraud?
Output: Yes, the non-destructive analytical technique of attenuated total Reflectance-Fourier Transform Infrared spectroscopy (ATR-FTIR) can be used to achieve the purpose of monitoring quality, traceability, and safety assessment of Italian Extra Virgin Olive Oil (EVOO) and prevent food fraud. This technique, coupled with Machine Learning algorithms, can analyze the EVOO data set from different regions to verify geographical traceability, cultivar, and the repeatability of agronomical practices. It can also detect adulterated EVOO from soy and corn. The use of ATR-FTIR in the related study eliminates the need for reagents or esterification processes and allows for analysis of the entire frequency range, reducing time and costs.
